Dialogue: No of course not. How can there be? If he is supposed to be loving and forgiving - what on earth is the sense punishing all these millions of souls.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: But just suppose if there was. And all this was punishment.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: All what?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I don't know what you mean. All what?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Pull!

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Talk to Mr Innes. Please. You are clearly not well 53

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: He is what? A physician now

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: You know what I mean. I think he can help you.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I am taking the children to Maer for a while, to visit their cousins.  I worry for you, Charles. Please talk to him

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Will you be eating sir. 54

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: No thank you.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Annie? .....Annie.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Annie!

Speaker: thatcher
Dialogue: Mr Darwin! Mr Darwin! I was explaining to Mr Goodman here your interest in breeding. Mr Darwin is our foremost scholar in the village.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: No. No I am but one of many. There is Squire Lubbock, and the reverend Innes

Speaker: thatcher
Dialogue: ....he is also a noted explorer, the author of many books..

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: ...which no-one has read. 55

Speaker: thatcher
Dialogue: ...a fellow of the Royal society and a prodigious expert on clams...oysters?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Barnacles.

Speaker: thatcher
Dialogue: Mr Goodman, now, is the foremost pigeon fancier in all the southern counties. Kent champion two years running. I swear he can give you any beak or plumage in four generations. Head and tail in five.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: How do you do it?

Speaker: gooodman
Dialogue: By breeding cousin with cousin. I find it the fastest way to alter the strain - provided you do not weaken it in other ways.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Get rid of them.

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Which ones sir?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: All of them. All of it.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Go. Go!

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Sir. Mr Darwin.

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Please rest sir. I'll have John Lewis remove it. Have some breakfast now and rest. Shall I call the doctor?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: God know.

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Or the water tower.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: A pox on all of them!

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Calomel then, twice daily.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I will not give it to her.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Not to any of mine I hope. On the Beagle I dropped some on a microscope slide and all my animacules died of it.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Well animacules are not persons. Presumably they would die if you dose them with Madeira wine.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: On Madeira they thrived most excellently, as did Captain Fitzroy, while it lasted.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Or if she would submit to be bled.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Please no.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I will write to Dr Gully again.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: The hydro-therapist?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I have always found his treatments most effective.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: ...no matter that they defy all sense of logic.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Logic is not everything.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: Then I shall bid you good day.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Parslow will bring your carriage. I will be down presently

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I should take her to Malvern.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I think it is better she is here.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Gully can care for her properly there. She can be treated daily, as I was.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Charles no. She is better with us. With her family. Please do not take her away from me.

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Post for you sir.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Ha!!

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: Ah, there you are Mr Darwin.

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: May I join you.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: By odd means

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: Mrs Darwin informed me you would be alone and ....perhaps a need to counsel.

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: You dropped this. What a beautiful postage stamp.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Yes. It is from the Spice islands.

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: I do rather envy your wide circle of correspondents. In my youth I always wanted to travel.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: You are still young. You could be a missionary and follow in Mr Livingstone's footsteps.

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: Yes, although I have always felt there is quite enough evil at home without looking for it abroad.  Mrs Darwin told me of the book you are writing.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Not any more, thank goodness

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: You have finished it?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: It has been finished for me. My correspondent In the spice islands has arrived independently at exactly the same idea, expressed in a mere twenty pages.  61

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: The Lord moves in mysterious ways.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: He does indeed Mr Innes. I was reflecting only the other day on the fact that he has endowed us in his blessed generosity with not one but nine hundred species of intestinal worm each with its own unique method of infiltrating the blood supply and burrowing through the mucosa.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: And then again on the great love he shows for butterflies by inventing a wasp to lay eggs inside the living flesh of caterpillars

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: Well. It is not for us to guess at His reasons.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: No. We can leave that for Mr Wallace now. Should I advise him to stay overseas do you think? If he shows his face in Kent he may be required to kneel on rock salt.

Speaker: innes
Dialogue: I once valued our friendship Mr Darwin. I had hoped it might be possible to restore it. Clearly in your present mood that is not going to be possible. My regards to Mrs Darwin

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: What? I am forestalled by Mr Wallace. That is the simple fact of it. What reason do you have to be angry?!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Annie!

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: You have a visitor.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: No. No. I will not be bled or lectured to.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: It is me. Thank God you are still with us. Word came from London you had suffered an apoplectic stroke.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: No. Simply the great relief of liberation. Did you read the Wallace abstract.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: It is a letter. You have a book

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: ...barely half of it

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: You have a book. What is not already on the page is most certainly inside your head and I intend to extract it, if it kills us both.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: You have been talking to Huxley.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: No. Had I done so he would have hastened here himself armed with every instrument of torture known to her majesty's navy.  Charles I have read the first Chapters. It is brilliant. You must continue.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I cannot. Seriously Joseph, I am completely blocked. All my old symptoms have returned with a vengeance. The sweats the shakes the abdominal pains. The whole endeavour was cursed from the outset.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Charles. It was you who opened my eyes to the wonders of science. So let me open yours. You have an illness. You have had it as long as I have known you.  64

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Not Malvern

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: Why not. What is there to be scared of there. He has worked for you in the past it will work again. Then come back and finish the book. Your enemies are already toasting their good fortune but they shall not prevail.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: What are you talking about. I have no enemies.

Speaker: hooker
Dialogue: They are legion, believe me, and they are implacable. We are all of us fighting a battle against fear and superstition but we can win this battle. We must win it. You can win it for all of us. Go to malvern, then come back and finish it.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Charles, please reconsider

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: Emma it is weeks now, months. She is getting worse, not better.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Then I am coming with you. 65

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: You cannot come. How can you possibly come in your condition.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: It is not so far.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: It is two days by coach and train. Who will look after the others.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I do not care for the others. I care for Annie!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Leave us please, Etty.

Speaker: brodie
Dialogue: Make sure she is tucked in. Watch her shawl

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I don't need to go.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: The coach is outside. I will carry her from here.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Annie...

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Mama...

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: You will see Mamma when you are better. Say goodbye now. 66

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Wait. I am coming with you

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Please, Emma

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Wait there.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Get aboard. Brodie

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Mama!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Go. Go.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Wait!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Go now!

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Mama!! 67

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Charles. Please God. No. Annie!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Tell him not this way.

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: Hello there. Stop. Can we go by the other route

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: The Worcester Road is shorter.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: ...by the low road.

Speaker: parslow
Dialogue: He wishes to go by the other route.

Speaker: attendant
Dialogue: As you will sir.

Speaker: mr gully
Dialogue: Mr Darwin, old friend. Mr Darwin. It has been too long I fear. Tut tut tut tut tut. What have we now what have we now?

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: tongue...

Speaker: mr gully
Dialogue: Ugh. Shirt up. Let me feel your liver.

Speaker: dr gully
Dialogue: Pulse hectic, togue furred, liver tender and enlarged.

Speaker: dr gully
Dialogue: No doubt you have been exercising your brain every hour that God gave you.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I was persuaded to write book.

Speaker: dr gully
Dialogue: Madness there are far too many of those already. Are you Sleeping?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Poorly.

Speaker: dr gully
Dialogue: I suppose never taking the 50C dilution of Chelidonium.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I had the gardener build a water tower. It no longer has any effect.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: Of course not. Your gardener is not a hydrotherapist. What on earth possessed you ?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I feared I was dying.

Speaker: dr gully
Dialogue: Oh come come come. We shall not have that talk here.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: A smart spinal scrub. Cold douche daily at 7.00. Wrapping in towels and sweating by the lamp.

Speaker: dr gully
Dialogue: No red meat, no reading, no mental agitation of any kind. We shall soon have you right old friend, we shall have you right.

Speaker: bearded stranger
Dialogue: Mr Darwin is it?

Speaker: bearded strange
Dialogue: William Carter of Southampton. I read your Beagle account many years ago. Former naval man myself. What brings you here? Myself, a Bilious fever with blood per rectum, but I have every faith in Gully. The man is a miracle worker. 71

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: What action do you most associate with the symptoms. Eating? Strong emotion? Strenuous Excercise?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Does the exercise of memory count as an action.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: Memory of what.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: My eldest daughter. You remember her.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: Of course. Of course. You must accept there was nothing more we could do.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I know that. I know.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: You say you were writing about her.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: No. It is a scientific text. But I had reached a point, beyond which it was impossible to progress. She had been my companion throughout. Now it seemed she was ahead of me in a place I could not follow. 72

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: Of course. Plainly she is in heaven.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: That is what my wife believes. It is a great consolation to her

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: But not to you.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Emma and I have become ...divided on it.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: Does it affect your marital relations.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: We have none ...to speak of.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: Are you familiar with the writings of DeQuincy."There is no such thing known to the mind as forgetting."

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I don't know what it means.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: He suggests we have thoughts which do not actually enter the realm of consciousness. Nervous fibres exist after all throughout the whole body. Is it not possible that certain primal feelings manifest in some physical way. Eczema. Boils. A fever. Might some blocked passion imitate a gall-stone? Or even manufacture one.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Well, until someone devises a machine to read nervous impulses, or a telescope to look inside the body I suppose we can only guess at it.

Speaker: gully
Dialogue: We can Mr Darwin. We can look inside you. If you find yourself open to it, there is a way of seeing. 73

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Mrs St John?

Speaker: st john
Dialogue: Just leave your coat on the table. Sit down here. Show me your palm.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Sorry. I'm confused. What is it you do exactly.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Envision how? When Gully described you I fancied some scientific instrument....

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Well. I have a ten shilling note here in my wallet.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: If you can tell me the numbers on it we can begin.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I am a professional man. And I asking for no more than I ask of all my colleagues - a demonstration of competence.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Then I am sorry to have wasted your time.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: How dare you. 75

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: ...prey on people's grief like this.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Do you take me for an idiot? Clearly Gully has appraised you of my history.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: It is chicanery of the very lowest order and I despise it utterly!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Annie. Annie! 76

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Is Mrs Carey still the landlady here.

Speaker: landlord
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: My daughter Annie ...lodged here some years ago. Can I come in?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I know this is an intrusion. I wonder - could I visit the room she stayed in?

Speaker: landlord
Dialogue: Wait here. I'll get the missus.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: Which room?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Fourteen. I would only be there ten minutes. I am happy to pay.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: Up one flight and along the corridor to the right.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I remember.

Speaker: landlady
Dialogue: Try not to touch anything.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Is she any better? Does she want for anything?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Darling Annie. I am here now.

Speaker: brodie
Dialogue: There there. It will all soon be over.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Save her. I will believe whatever. Forever. Please save her

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Is that good, my lovely

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Beautifully good. I am making custards.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: The rabbit.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: The rabbit taught him the polka.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I don't understand my love.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Tell me about Jenny.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: What about her.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: When she died

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I don't want to talk about death my love.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: But tell me. I like it.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Well. What the keeper told me was. When she was very sick with pneumonia, lying very still, he tried to feed her but she shook her head, looking at him as though to say: "Its nice of you but really you shouldn't bother". And as he bent down to take the spoon away she brought her arms around his neck and kissed him. And then she was dead.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Sorry. I startled you. 83

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Take your coat off by the fire there. What time is it?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: We need to talk. I need to talk to you.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Of course, but dry your hair. I shall call for a towel.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I went back to Worcester Road. I saw Annie.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Charles. No.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Let me tell you.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I don't want to hear it. This must stop.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: You don't understand.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I do! Do you think me deaf and blind. You have lived with her and spoken with her every day since she died.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: She is more real to you than I am. She's dead Charles.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I know that.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Then what is wrong with you that even our poor daughter cannot be left in her grave but you would.... 84

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I know she is dead. I know it. It is you who will not accept the fact, preferring to think of her in heaven.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Get away from me!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Snowy white wings and dancing with the angels. Is that your idea of honesty.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Why did you come back. I will not hear this!

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: You have to Emma, everything these was between us is gone. The boat is wrecked and sunk now. We have to hold to something else.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: To what. Your ghosts? Your theories? What Charles.

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: To the truth of what we know it.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Open this door Emma. The truth, how wonderful and extraordinary our daughter was....

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I know that. I do not need you to say it. Of course I know. 85

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: But free of the fantasy, free of the rest, the silly vain hope that we will be reunited in heaven and the nagging unspoken belief that I killed her!

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I have never said that

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: Say it now. Say it. And all the rest that follows. That I should have kept Annie warm that day on the beach. I should not have taken her to Malvern. I should have let you come.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I should have insisted.

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: No. It was me. I took her from you It was my fault.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I could have followed. I was her mother what was I thinking of.

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: We thought she would live. You were not to know.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I did. I did know. I knew when you left that I would never see her again. I hated you for taking her.

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: I hated myself. I knew that none of them could save her.  86

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: What are you saying?

Speaker: charles
Dialogue: The unspeakable . I am saying that you and I, in making our perfect child, endowed her with the very weakness which killed her. Emma. That is what I couldn't write. That is what forestalled me all these years. It wasn't you I was angry with, it wasn't Innes and it wasn't God. I was angry with my theory. It was the truth I was angry with. It is the truth.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: Tell me a story.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I'm busy Annie.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: I'll go away again, then you'll be sorry.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: All right, come here, come here.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Once there was a man Who, while travelling in South America, came apon a beautiful and dangerous idea.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Here, here. Come on, come on then

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: ...I wont hurt you.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: He knew his wife wouldn't care for this creature so when he came home he locked it in a box, where it couldn't run around and do any damage.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: But every so often he'd open the lid and feed it, just because he couldn't bear to let it die.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: One day he opened the box and discovered it wasn't in there at all. It had escaped with all its babies, who were nesting all over the house making a terrible mess.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: But finally they caught them all, and bundled them in a blanket and he asked his wife to dispose of them as she saw fit.

Speaker: annie
Dialogue: And what did she do?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: I don't know but I fancy she took them out in the garden and set them free.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Done. I have finally got it out of the air and into these pages. Will you read it and decide what must be done with it. I confess I no longer know and I am very tired.  She takes his hand and squeezes it.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Emma?

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: Did you read it?

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: darwin
Dialogue: And....

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: I wrapped it and put it on the table there.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: You're right. True or not it must all be said. Probably most of it is true. God help us.

Speaker: emma
Dialogue: Careful. I have soot all over my hands.
